title: Keir Starmer ‘disappointed’ by Labour’s rejection of firm Remain stance
text:
Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer | Daniel Leal-Olivas/AFP via Getty Images Keir Starmer ‘disappointed’ by Labour’s rejection of firm Remain stance Labour members voted against a motion which would have seen the party commit to backing Remain in a second vote.

BRIGHTON, England — Labour's Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer said he was "disappointed" the party had not voted to back Remain in any future second referendum, but insisted it was "obvious" members would eventually back staying in the EU.

Speaking to POLITICO London Playbook at Labour Party conference, Starmer said he would have liked to have seen the party go further in its stance, but hailed "progress" over the past 12 months in shifting Labour's stance to backing a second referendum in all circumstances.

Earlier on Monday Labour members voted against a motion which would have seen the party commit to backing Remain in a second vote, despite calls from Starmer and other shadow cabinet figures for the party to wholeheartedly back staying in the EU.

"We had a vote and the vote went the way it did. I've said for some time, over and over again, I would campaign for Remain so obviously I'm disappointed by the result [but] sometimes we obscure the progress we've made by getting too hung up on this particular vote," Starmer said.

Members instead endorsed Jeremy Corbyn's policy of renegotiating a Brexit deal before holding a referendum, then holding a special conference to decide on the party's stance in the referendum — whether to back their new deal, or back staying in the EU.

Corbyn has suggested he could remain neutral on the question, a stance Starmer said he had "mixed feelings" about.

"Brexit is a very very difficult issue for the Labour Party," he said. "What Jeremy's trying to achieve, in fairness is — given the divisions across the country — somebody's got to be prepared to say: 'We'll have a referendum to find a way through and I'll stay above that' ... I personally think it's better to campaign for Remain and that's what I've said. I don't think there is a deal that's going to be as good as the deal we've got."

Predicting the outcome of any special conference on Brexit, Starmer said: "I think it is very likely that the members will want us to campaign for Remain ... it seems to me obvious where the membership is on this."

In his speech to Labour conference, Starmer said Labour, if it was in government, would legislate to hold a referendum within six months.
description: Labour members voted against a motion which would have seen the party commit to backing Remain in a second vote.
